i need to update statefulButton from publishButton (publishButton contains the statefulButton directive). If I simply disable publishButton, statefulButton doesn't get the message. is it possible to disable a whole directive?
i only know that i need to disable statefulButton while inside of publishButton. I need to just disable the whole thing, so is it possible to add something like stateful-button.disable?

message.div: i can't find the SO post
should have used jsfiddle, i don't know how to load angular

div.span: wait so are you just saying to add another directive into publishbutton?

message.div: just put that on the thing you want to disable
it stops all ng-click directives from working

div.span: sorry. am i to understand correctly:
this is a standalone directive, with its own scope and link function, etc. and in order to use it.... i set aDisable to true? i'm still lost. even with all that code...

message.div: i noticed that it works on anchor tags
so I'm not sure it will work on buttons

div.span: i think mine's a trickier case
i only know your {{downloadLog}} inside of my publishButton
so it's there that i need to change it

message.div: so your publish button has a on.click event, right?

div.span: but inside the publishbutton or div or a or whatever it is

message.div: so it seems like this will work for ng-clicks only

div.span: it knows whether it's enabled or disabled
so it needs to let statefulbutton know
i think i just need to figure out a way to get it in scope
that's what i was trying to do beforehand, but nada. i'll try more

message.div: and you're passing the scoped parameter through both directives?
and on the tags as well?

div.span: cause statefulbutton is inside of publishbutton and so gets set first, and by the time i know about whether i should disable (inside of publish button) stateful has already been set

message.div: ah, yeah that'll do the trick
